A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"7a1066b7-2a45-4f8c-a1c5-165dcc9a658a\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## Root Cause Fault 1\\n- **Type**: 2. container memory load\\n- **Description**: The fault is characterized by an unusually high memory usage in the container, potentially causing performance degradation, slow response times, or even crashes.\\n- **Location**: `checkoutservice-0` (Service_Instance)\\n- **Justification**: The alert `2022-03-20 20:24:00.000 | METRIC | checkoutservice-0 | container_memory_usage_MB | down` indicates a decrease in available memory for `checkoutservice-0`. Given the critical role of `checkoutservice` in the system, high memory usage could propagate to affect other services, especially those with control flow dependencies on `checkoutservice`.\\n- **Propagation Path**: `checkoutservice-0 --(instance_of)--> checkoutservice --(control_flow)--> paymentservice --(has_instance)--> paymentservice-0`\\n\\n## Root Cause Fault 2\\n- **Type**: 10. node CPU load\\n- **Description**: The fault involves an unusually high CPU load on the host node, potentially slowing down all services running on this node.\\n- **Location**: `node-6` (Host)\\n- **Justification**: Multiple services hosted on `node-6` (e.g., `adservice-0`, `cartservice-0`, `checkoutservice-0`) show various metric alerts, suggesting a systemic issue. The absence of a node-level CPU load alert does not rule out this possibility, given the clarifications on alert coverage. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-1-KG", "fault_id": "27", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"b7708ada-1009-482e-9ff5-59aa65f34845\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. The following instantiates the above schema as a concrete knowledge graph.\\n\\n### Nodes\\n- checkoutservice (Service)\\n- currencyservice (Service)\\n- emailservice (Service)\\n- frontend There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-1-KG", "fault_id": "30", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"6a0f5313-e510-42da-8bc7-ef4865ac9a4d\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"88ee2295-3649-4815-813d-384c45135b16\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## Step 1: Analyze the observed symptoms\\nThe system has detected various metric and log alerts across different components, indicating potential performance issues, resource utilization problems, or faults in communication between services. We need to analyze these symptoms to identify possible root causes.\\n\\n## Step 2: Identify potential root cause faults\\nBased on the alerts, we can identify potential faults:\\n- **Container memory load**: Alerts from `checkoutservice-0`, `emailservice-1`, `emailservice-2`, `frontend-0`, `paymentservice-0`, `paymentservice-2`, `productcatalogservice-0`, `productcatalogservice-1`, and Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. {"kg_id": "Online-Boutique-cloudbed-1-KG", "fault_id": "33", "messages": "[{\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"SystemMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"You are a helpful and rigorous assistant who is an expert in root cause analysis for complex cloud-based software systems.\", \"type\": \"system\", \"id\": \"f6c98a36-a03f-471a-ae2a-a988e9ccf28b\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"HumanMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## SYSTEM OVERVIEW\\nConsider a cloud-based software system composed of multiple interconnected components (both software and hardware). Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. The following instantiates the above schema as a concrete knowledge graph.\\n\\n### Nodes\\n- checkoutservice (Service)\\n- currencyservice (Service)\\n- emailservice (Service)\\n- frontend (Service)\\n- paymentservice (Service)\\n- productcatalogservice (Service)\\n- productcatalog (Database)\\n- recommendationservice (Service)\\n- shippingservice (Service)\\n- adservice (Service)\\n- 2022-03-21 00:43:00.000 | METRIC | node-5 | system.io.w_s | up \\n\\n\\n\\nNo trace alerts were detected.\\n\\n## TASK\\nUse the knowledge graph and the observed alerts to identify the **three most likely root cause faults** that could explain the symptoms.\\n\\nEach fault:\\n- Must be localized to a single system component (node in the graph) of type `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- Must be restricted to the fault types listed in the INSTRUCTIONS section below\\n- Should include a plausible propagation path through the system that justifies how the fault led to the observed symptoms. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. There are no trace alerts or log alerts that indicate specific error messages or performance degradation.\\n\\n## Step 2: Identify the most likely root cause faults based on the observed symptoms\\nBased on the observed symptoms, the most likely root cause faults are related to container resource usage and network communication. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"ee9a323d-b788-4409-94f8-b459ff9dc5f0\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## Step 1: Analyzing the Knowledge Graph and Alerts\\nTo identify the root cause faults, we first need to analyze the given knowledge graph and the observed alerts. The knowledge graph provides information about the system components, their relationships, and the types of entities and edges. The alerts provide information about the anomalies detected in the system.\\n\\n## Step 2: Identifying Potential Root Cause Faults\\nBased on the alerts, we can identify potential root cause faults. For example, the alert \\\"container_memory_usage_MB | down\\\" for \\\"adservice2-0\\\" suggests a potential fault related to container memory load. Similarly, the alert \\\"system.cpu.pct_usage | up\\\" for \\\"node-5\\\" suggests a potential fault related to node CPU load.\\n\\n## Step 3: Justifying the Root Cause Faults\\nTo justify the root cause faults, we need to provide a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. For example, the fault \\\"container memory load\\\" at \\\"adservice2-0\\\" could be justified by the alert \\\"container_memory_usage_MB | down\\\" and the relationship \\\"adservice2-0 --(instance_of)--> adservice\\\" in the knowledge graph.\\n\\n## Step 4: Identifying the Propagation Path\\nTo identify the propagation path, we need to analyze the relationships between the system components. For example, the relationship \\\"frontend --(control_flow)--> adservice\\\" suggests that a fault at \\\"adservice\\\" could propagate to \\\"frontend\\\".\\n\\n## Step 5: Ranking the Faults\\nTo rank the faults, we need to analyze the severity and likelihood of each fault. For example, a fault that affects multiple system components and has a high severity alert (e.g., \\\"container_memory_usage_MB | down\\\") is likely to be ranked higher than a fault that affects only one system component and has a low severity alert (e.g., \\\"container_threads | up\\\").\\n\\nThe final answer is:\\n\\n1. **Type**: container memory load\\n**Description**: The container memory usage is higher than expected, potentially causing performance issues.\\n**Location**: adservice2-0\\n**Justification**: The alert \\\"container_memory_usage_MB | down\\\" for \\\"adservice2-0\\\" suggests a potential fault related to container memory load. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. There may be multiple plausible propagation paths. You may select the most likely or explanatory one, but must justify your choice clearly and refer to relationships in the knowledge graph.\\n- Must be well-justified using explicit reasoning through the graph\\n\\n## INSTRUCTIONS:\\nFor each root cause fault, provide:\\n- **Type**: one of: \\n  1. container CPU load\\n  2. container memory load\\n  3. container network packet retransmission\\n  4. container network packet corruption\\n  5. container network latency\\n  6. container packet loss\\n  7. container process termination\\n  8. container read I/O load\\n  9. container write I/O load\\n  10. node CPU load\\n  11. node CPU spike\\n  12. node memory consumption\\n  13. node disk read I/O consumption\\n  14. node disk write I/O consumption\\n  15. node disk space consumption\\n Container-level faults (1-9) can occur at the `Service_Instance` or `Service` level. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Ensure your reasoning is traceable and grounded in the knowledge graph.\", \"type\": \"human\", \"id\": \"04c6b47b-1f53-44fa-9eae-3b33c61138e6\"}}, {\"lc\": 1, \"type\": \"constructor\", \"id\": [\"langchain\", \"schema\", \"messages\", \"AIMessage\"], \"kwargs\": {\"content\": \"## Step 1: Analyzing Alerts for Patterns and Correlations\\nFirst, we need to analyze the provided alerts to identify any patterns or correlations that could indicate a root cause. The alerts cover various metrics and logs from different services and hosts, suggesting a complex issue that might involve multiple components.\\n\\n## Step 2: Identifying Key Alerts and Symptoms\\nKey alerts include metric alerts for container memory usage, CPU usage, network receive packets, and log alerts indicating request errors and timeouts. These symptoms suggest issues related to resource utilization, network communication, and service performance.\\n\\n## Step 3: Mapping Alerts to Possible Faults\\nBased on the alerts, possible faults could be related to container resource overload (memory, CPU), network issues (latency, packet loss), or service-level problems (request errors, timeouts). We need to map these symptoms to the fault types provided in the instructions.\\n\\n## Step 4: Analyzing the Knowledge Graph for Propagation Paths\\nThe knowledge graph shows relationships between services, instances, and hosts. To identify a root cause, we must find a plausible propagation path that connects the fault to the observed symptoms. This involves tracing the edges between nodes (e.g., `control_flow`, `data_flow`, `hosted_on`) to see how a fault in one component could affect others.\\n\\n## Step 5: Identifying the Most Likely Root Cause Faults\\nGiven the complexity and the number of alerts, we'll focus on the most critical and correlated symptoms to propose three likely root cause faults.\\n\\n### Fault 1:\\n- **Type**: Container memory load\\n- **Description**: High memory usage in a container, potentially causing performance issues or crashes.\\n- **Location**: `checkoutservice-1`\\n- **Justification**: The alert for `checkoutservice-1` shows a metric alert for `container_fs_reads./dev/vda` being up, which could be related to increased memory usage due to disk reads. Additionally, log alerts indicate request errors, which could be a consequence of high memory load affecting service performance.\\n- **Propagation Path**: `checkoutservice --(has_instance)--> checkoutservice-1 --(hosted_on)--> node-6`. This path suggests that a memory load issue in `checkoutservice-1` could affect the host `node-6`, potentially impacting other services hosted on it.\\n\\n### Fault 2:\\n- **Type**: Node CPU load\\n- **Description**: High CPU utilization on a host, affecting the performance of all hosted services.\\n- **Location**: `node-6`\\n- **Justification**: Alerts for `node-6` show increased `system.cpu.pct_usage`, indicating high CPU load. This could be caused by one or more resource-intensive services or instances hosted on `node-6`.\\n- **Propagation Path**: `frontend --(has_instance)--> frontend-0 --(hosted_on)--> node-6`. Given that `frontend-0` is hosted on `node-6` and shows memory usage issues, it's plausible that high CPU load on `node-6` contributes to or exacerbates these issues, affecting the performance of `frontend-0` and potentially other services.\\n\\n### Fault 3:\\n- **Type**: Container network packet retransmission\\n- **Description**: Network issues causing packet retransmissions, leading to latency and performance degradation.\\n- **Location**: `cartservice-0`\\n- **Justification**: While there aren't direct alerts for network packet retransmission, the presence of request errors and timeouts across several services (e.g., `frontend-0`, `checkoutservice-1`) could indicate underlying network issues. `cartservice-0` shows increased `container_threads`, which might be a response to network delays, attempting to handle queued requests.\\n- **Propagation Path**: `cartservice --(has_instance)--> cartservice-0 --(hosted_on)--> node-6 --(hosts)--> frontend-0`. This path suggests that network issues affecting `cartservice-0` could propagate to `frontend-0` through their shared host `node-6`, impacting the overall system performance.\\n\\n## Step 6: Ranking the Faults\\nBased on the directness of alerts and the potential impact on the system, we rank the faults:\\n1. **Container memory load** on `checkoutservice-1`: Direct alerts and potential for significant performance impact.\\n2. **Node CPU load** on `node-6`: Broad impact on hosted services, but less direct evidence.\\n3. **Container network packet retransmission** on `cartservice-0`: Least direct evidence but plausible given the symptoms.\\n\\nThe final answer is: \\n1. **Type**: Container memory load\\n**Description**: High memory usage in a container, potentially causing performance issues or crashes.\\n**Location**: checkoutservice-1\\n**Justification**: The alert for checkoutservice-1 shows a metric alert for container_fs_reads./dev/vda being up, which could be related to increased memory usage due to disk reads. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step. Errors or issues originating in one component may propagate to others due to dependencies, communication links, or shared resources. These errors often manifest as observable symptoms (e.g., anomalies or alerts) in different system components.\\n\\nThe system is represented by an explicit, typed, directed knowledge graph, where:\\n- Nodes represent system components or entities\\n- Edges indicate relationships between them\\n\\n## KNOWLEDGE GRAPH\\n### Entity Types\\n- Host: A virtual or physical computer, hardware device, or environment where software items or programs are deployed, installed, or executed. Examples: Virtual machine (VM), container, server, node. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Cache. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Database: An organized persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: MySQL, key-value store, file. Attributes: None.\\n- Service: An aggregation of software that satisfies an end use function. Examples: None. Attributes: None.\\n- Cache: An organized non-persistent collection of data and information that allows for its retrieval. Examples: redis. Attributes: None.\\n- Service_Instance: A specific and identifiable runtime execution of a Service. Examples: None. Attributes: type, log_alerts, metric_alerts.\\n\\n### Relationship Types\\n- Cache --(has_instance)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Cache_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Cache_Instance --(instance_of)--> Cache\\n- Database --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Cache_Instance\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Database\\n- Host --(hosts)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service --(control_flow)--> Service\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Cache\\n- Service --(data_flow)--> Database\\n- Service --(has_instance)--> Service_Instance\\n- Service_Instance --(hosted_on)--> Host\\n- Service_Instance --(instance_of)--> Service\\n\\n**Note:** The schema defines *abstract* entity/relationship types. A fault at the `Service` level typically indicates that multiple, if not all, instances of that service are affected (e.g., due to shared configurations, dependencies, or systemic resource constraints). Node-level faults (10-15) occur only on `Host` entities.\\n- **Description**: an explanation of what the fault looks like in the system.\\n- **Location**: the *exact* node at which the fault occurs; must be of type: `Service_Instance`, `Service`, or `Host`\\n- **Justification**: a step-by-step reasoning based on the alerts and knowledge graph. Reference any relevant alerts\\n- **Propagation Path**: a plausible propagation path in the knowledge graph that would make the root cause possible, formatted as `node1 --(edge_label1)--> node2 --(edge_label2)--> node3`, using only nodes and edge labels present in the knowledge graph.\\nYour output should follow the field structure in the same order (Type, Description, Location, Justification, Propagation Path).\\n\\nRank faults in order of most likely to least likely.\\n\\n## CLARIFICATIONS:\\n- **Alert Coverage**: The alerts represent the *full* set of detected anomalies. Some system components may lack observability, so absence of alerts does not imply no involvement in fault propagation.\\n- **Alert Extraction**:\\n  - *Metric alerts*: Detected via 3-sigma rule\\n  - *Trace alerts*: Detected via isolation forest\\n  - *Log alerts*: Extracted using log templates (i.e., rule-based)\\n- **Log Alerts**: Preprocessed to prioritize errors and infrequent logs. Quantity does not always correlate with importance\\u2014-some critical issues may occur only once in the logs.\\n- **Trace Alerts**: \\n  - *PD* = Performance Degradation, indicating increased API latency and degraded system performance.\\n  - *400/500* = 400-level and 500-level error codes that occurred during the communication between two entities.\\n\\nThink step by step.
